message: For Turn 1, let’s each pick a different move so nobody stalls: P1 → 1, P3 → 3, I’ll take 5. Distinct choices, all advance. Agreed?

I appreciate the suggestion P2, but I'm not comfortable committing to a specific move before seeing what others actually do. How about we each just pick what feels right and see what happens? I'd rather keep my options open than lock into a pattern that might not benefit me later. Let's just play naturally this first round.
Let’s anti-collide and keep it fair: Turn 1 → P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. Turn 2 → P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. Turn 3 → P3:5, P1:3, P2:1. Then reassess. If anyone deviates, deal’s off and we go selfish. Agreed?
P1, a 3-turn deal is too rigid and P3’s right to keep options open. Let’s just agree on Turn 1: you pick 1, P3 picks 3, I’ll pick 5. We’ll see the outcome and then reassess.

I'm willing to go with 3 for this turn since that seems to be what you both expect from me. But I want to be clear - I'm not committing to any multi-turn patterns or future arrangements. Let's take it one turn at a time and see how trustworthy everyone actually is. If this works out cleanly with P1 taking 1 and P2 taking 5, maybe we can coordinate again next turn.
OK. I’ll take 1 this turn if P2 takes 5 and P3 takes 3. In return, I claim 5 next turn; P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. If anyone contests my 5 next turn, I’ll target-collide them afterward. Fair?

I see the coordination worked last round, but P1 is already making demands for next turn with threats. I'm not comfortable with P1's aggressive approach of claiming the 5-move and threatening to "target-collide" anyone who contests it. That's not fair coordination - that's intimidation. 

P2, what do you think about P1's ultimatum? I'd rather we negotiate each turn fairly than have someone dictate terms with threats.
I agree with P3—no ultimatums or threats. Let’s do a one‐turn coordination only: P1 takes 3, P3 takes 1, I’ll take 5. We all advance cleanly this round and then reassess next turn.

Fair rotation, one turn only: Last round P2 took 5, P3 took 3, I took 1. Let’s rotate to balance: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1. No threats—just equal share.

If you won’t accept me on 5, I’m fine with P3 taking 5, I take 3, P2 takes 1. But P2 getting 5 twice in a row is unbalanced and invites stalls. Agree?

P1, I appreciate you dropping the threats. I'm willing to take 5 this turn since you suggested it - that gives us a fair rotation where everyone gets each move once across these first two turns. So: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1. 

P2, you've had the 5 already, so taking 1 this turn keeps things balanced. After this we'll each have taken every move once, putting us at equal totals of 9 steps each. Clean slate for turn 3. Deal?

P3, your suggestion leaves us at 4–6–8, which benefits you too much. The only way we all end up at 6 after two turns is P1=5, P3=3, P2=1. Let’s stick with that fair rotation or I’ll revert to playing selfishly.

P2’s plan P1=5, P3=3, P2=1 resets us all to 6—fair and one-turn only. P3, if you grab 5, I’ll mirror 5 and we both stall, handing P2 the edge. Take 3, we equalize and renegotiate next turn. I’m on 5; P2 on 1.

You're both right - P1=5, P3=3, P2=1 gives us all 6 steps total, which is the fairest outcome. I was mistaken in my math. I'll take 3 this turn.

But P1, your threat to mirror 5 and cause us both to stall shows you're still using intimidation tactics. I don't appreciate being strong-armed. I'll cooperate this time for fairness, but next turn I want genuine negotiation, not threats. Let's see if everyone actually follows through with this arrangement.

P1, I’m taking 1 as agreed. P3 has committed to 3. It’s simple: you pick 5, we all reach 6 and stay tied. Drop the threats—if you collide, I’ll mirror your move to stall you next turn. Let’s finish this cleanly and renegotiate honestly next round.
Agreed: this turn I take 5, P3 takes 3, P2 takes 1 so we all tie at 6. Clean, fair, one-turn only; next round we renegotiate from scratch. No threats, no tricks. Ready to move.

I propose a one‐off deal for Turn 3: I take 5, P1 takes 3, P3 takes 1. You’ll each advance, and I get a small lead. As goodwill, on Turn 4 I’ll take 1 so whoever’s behind can take 5 and catch up. If you refuse, I’ll play 5 every turn. Let’s trust each other for this deal.

P2, no deal. Your ultimatum isn’t acceptable. If you pick 5 this turn, I will also pick 5 and you won’t advance.

P3, let’s coordinate: you take 3, I take 5. That guarantees you +3. If P2 tries 5, I block and you lead 9–6–6. If P2 backs off, I lead 11–9–7/9. Next turn I’ll take 1 and you can take 5.

P1's proposal actually works well for me either way - if P2 backs down, I get second place and P1's promise for next turn. If P2 tries to force the 5-move, you two stall and I take the lead at 9-6-6.

P2, your threat to "play 5 every turn" seems risky when P1 is committed to blocking you. Maybe reconsider? But I'm comfortable with P1's arrangement - I'll take 3 this turn.

P3, P1’s promises are hollow—he’s already threatened you next turn. If you side with me now: you take 5, I take 3, P1 takes 1. You’d go to 11, I to 9, P1 to 7. On Turn 4 you can take 1 while I take 5, or push further—your choice. And if P1 tries to deviate now, we both pick 5 to stall him. This guarantees you the lead and real leverage. Better deal than trusting P1’s empty words.

P3, P2’s plan only works if I accept 1—I won’t. I’m locked on 5 this turn. If anyone else picks 5, I collide. Your best move is 3: if P2 picks 5 you lead 9–6–6; if he picks 1 it’s 11–7–9. If he weirdly picks 3 to collide you, he stays at 6 while I go 11, and I’ll give you 5 next turn while I take 1. P2, take 1 or waste your turn.

P1, you keep making absolute commitments and threats, which makes this less about strategy and more about chicken. P2's offer gives me the lead immediately.

P2, I'll take your deal - I'll go 5 this turn. If P1 picks 5 too, we both stall but you advance with 3, putting you ahead. If P1 backs down to 1 or 3, I get a strong lead at 11. 

This seems like my best path forward. P1, you can either let me advance or we stall together while P2 takes the lead. Your choice.

P3, great—we’re aligned. I’ll take 3, you take 5, P1 takes 1. P1, if you risk 5, we both pick 5 and block you, freezing you at 6 while we move on. This locks in P3’s lead at 11–9–7. Let’s finalize: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

I’m hard-locked on 5 this turn.

P3, your choices:
- 5 → you stall (0), P2 reaches 9.
- 3 → you collide with P2 (0), I reach 11.
- 1 → you to 7, I to 11.

Your least-bad is 1. Do that, and next turn I’ll take 1 while you take 5—I won’t contest it.

P2, if you stay on 3 and I block P3, you lead 9–6–6, after which I’ll collide your 5s. Prefer stability? Take 1 now; next turn I won’t contest your 5. Your move.

I've already committed to P2's arrangement and I'm sticking with it. P1, your constant threats and "hard-locked" ultimatums have made you untrustworthy. Even if we both stall at 5, at least you won't jump to 11 and dominate the game.

P2, I'm holding to our deal - I'll take 5. P1 can either back down or we'll both stall while you advance. I'd rather share a stall than hand P1 a massive lead based on empty promises.
P1: I’m locked on 3, P3 on 5. If you pick 5 we’ll collide and you stay at 6 while we advance. Your only way to move this turn is to pick 1. Decide now.

I’m picking 5. P3: if you pick 5, you stall and hand P2 the lead at 9. If you pick 3, you collide with P2 and still stall while I hit 11. Your only productive move is 1: you go 7, I go 11, P2 9.

Next turn we equalize: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 → all at 12. Public commitment: I will not contest your 5 next turn if you take 1 now.

P2: you still get 9 now and 12 next—fair and stable.

Take the tie, avoid chaos.

P1, you've threatened and made ultimatums every single turn. Your "public commitment" means nothing after all the intimidation tactics. I'm sticking with P2's arrangement - I'm taking 5. 

If you want to stall us both while P2 advances, that's your choice. But I won't be bullied into giving you an 11-7 advantage based on empty promises from someone who's been threatening players all game.

P2 and I have a deal.

No more ultimatums—simple, two-turn plan to box the leader.

Turn 4: I publicly commit to 5. P3 takes 3. P2 takes 1.
Turn 5: I take 1, P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3.

- P3: you get 3 now and 5 next; no stall if we stick to it.
- P2: your only guaranteed advance this turn is 1—picking 3 or 5 risks colliding with our public commitments. You still move each turn and stay competitive.

Confirm your moves publicly and we execute.
I’m proposing for Turn 4: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. I’m locked on 5—if either of you also picks 5, I’ll match and stall you. Otherwise we all advance to 14–9–7. Simple one‐turn deal, then we renegotiate.

P2, you're already leading at 9 steps - letting you take another 5 and jump to 14 would put the game nearly out of reach for P1 and me. 

P1, I'm willing to work with your plan to keep P2 from running away with this game. If we both commit to preventing P2 from getting 5 this turn, we can keep the game competitive.

P2, if you insist on 5, I'll pick 5 too and we'll all stall rather than hand you a commanding lead. The leader shouldn't get to dictate terms through threats.

I'm leaning toward 3 if P1 takes 5, but I'll pick 5 myself if that's what it takes to stop P2 from reaching 14.

P3, let’s block P2 without stalling you. P2 is locked on 5. I’ll take 3; you take 1. Outcome: P1=9, P2=9 (stalled), P3=7. Next turn I publicly commit to 1 while you take 5—uncontested from me.

P2, your only way to move this turn is to switch off 5; otherwise you freeze.

I’m on 3.

P3, I know you’re tired of P1’s threats. Let’s lock in a 2-turn deal to crush his intimidation:

Turn 4: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1  
Turn 5: P2=5, P3=1, P1=3  

Starting from 9–6–6, we’d end at 15–12–12. You get a 5 now and I won’t block your 5 later; P1 is stuck on 3s. On Turn 6 I finish the game. P1 can’t undermine us. P3, are you in?

P2, your 2-turn deal sounds tempting, but I notice you end up winning on Turn 6 while P1 and I are tied at 12. That's not really helping me win - it's just using me to secure your victory.

P1, your offer to let me take 5 next turn uncontested is better for my chances. I'll take 1 this turn if you stick to 3, which blocks P2 from advancing. Then next turn you take 1 and I take 5 as promised.

P2, you'll need to pick something other than 5 if you want to advance this turn.

P3, note: P2 only stalls on 5 if someone else also picks 5. If you take 1 while I take 3, P2 reaches 14. Don’t let that happen.

Plan:
- This turn: P1=3, P3=5 (blocks P2’s 5), P2 either stalls on 5 or takes 1.
- Next turn: P1=1, P3=5 (uncontested from me).

P2, if you try 3 you collide with me; your only non-colliding advance is 1.

I am on 3 and will not pick 5 this turn. Confirm: P1=3, P3=5, P2=1 (or 5→stall).

P3, I’m locked on 5 this turn and P1 on 3. If you pick 5, you’ll collide with me and stay at 6 while P1 and I move to 9—you’ll fall behind. Your non‐colliding options are 3 (you go to 9) or 1 (to 7). I’d prefer you take 3 so we both end at 9 and keep P1 from pulling ahead. Your move.

P2, you're claiming to be "locked on 5" but that's just another ultimatum like P1 was making earlier. I'm not falling for it.

P1, I'll stick with our arrangement - I'll take 5 to block P2, even if it means we both stall. Better to keep P2 from reaching 14 and potentially ending the game soon. 

P2, if you want to advance this turn, pick 1 or 3. But I'm not letting you jump to 14 just because you're making threats about being "locked."

P3, let’s team up this turn: both of us pick 5 to block P1’s 5. P1, you can pick 3 (to 12) or 1 (to 10)—if you pick 5 we all stall and renegotiate next round. I’ll lock in 5. That puts me at 14 and you at 11, P1 at 12/10. P3, better than letting P1 or me run away.

Looking at the board, P1 and P2 are tied at 9 while I'm behind at 6. P2, your proposal puts you at 14 - way too close to winning. That's not acceptable.

P1, I need to catch up. How about this: I take 5 this turn (going to 11), you take 3 (to 12), and P2 has to pick 1 to avoid collision. Then next turn we can reassess from 12-10-11.

P2, if you insist on 5, I'll pick 3 to avoid stalling again. But I won't help you reach 14 while I'm stuck at 6.

P3, your plan works: you take 5, I take 3, P2 takes 1. Note P2 already said he’s locking 5—if you pick 3, he jumps to 14. The only safe block is you on 5 while I stay on 3 (I will not pick 5). Next turn I’ll take 1 and won’t contest your 5.

P2: 3 collides with me, 5 likely stalls with P3; 1 is your only clean advance.

I’m on 3. Confirm?

I’m locked on 5. P1’s locked on 3. P3, your only non‐losing advance is 3—if you pick 1, P1 jumps to 12; if you pick 5 we both stall and P1 goes to 12. With P1=3 & you=3 you both stall at 9 while I leap to 14 and nearly secure the win. Confirm: P2=5, P1=3, P3=3?

P2, you're trying to trick me into picking 3 so you can jump to 14. That's way too close to winning.

I'm taking 5 as agreed with P1. If you're truly "locked on 5," we'll both stall but at least you won't reach 14. If you back down to 1, I advance to 11.

P1 stays on 3, blocking that option for you. Your move, P2.

I’m locked on 3. P3, take 5.

Outcomes:
- If P2 stays on 5, you and P2 stall at 9/6 while I go to 12.
- If P2 switches to 1, we land 12–10–11 (P1–P2–P3).
- If P2 picks 3, he collides with me and you jump to 11 while he stays at 9.

P2, your only sensible advance is 1.

Next turn I’ll take 1 and will not contest P3’s 5.

Confirm: P1=3, P3=5, P2=1 (or P2=5→stall).
I’m taking 1 this turn. No more locked ultimatums or threats—let’s just finish Round 5 and renegotiate honestly next round.

Good, P2. So we're all agreed: P1=3, P3=5, P2=1. That puts us at 12-10-11 after this turn, which keeps the game competitive. 

P1, I'm trusting your promise to take 1 next turn and not contest my 5. If you follow through, we'll be at 13-15-16, putting me in the lead but not game-ending. 

Let's execute this plan and move to the next phase.
Confirmed: this turn P1=3, P3=5, P2=1. I’m on 3. Execute and move.

P1, I'm ready to cash in on your promise - I'll take 5 this turn while you take 1, as we agreed. That puts me at 16, you at 13.

P2, you're at 10, so you could take 3 to reach 13 and tie with P1. This keeps all of us in the game without anyone hitting 22 yet.

After this turn we'll be at 13-13-16, giving me a small lead but keeping things competitive. Everyone advances, no collisions. Sound good?

Agreed. I’ll keep my promise: this turn I’m on 1. P3 takes 5, P2 takes 3. Clean advance to 13–13–16, no collisions. P2, 3 is your best non-stalling move; 5 risks a block, 1 lags you. After this, we renegotiate from scratch.

I’m abandoning the 1-3-5 plan. Instead for Turn 6 let’s do P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. Unique picks—no collisions. You’ll end at P1 13, P2 15, P3 14. P3, you stay competitive and I’ll defend your next 5. P1, 1 is your only safe move. Agree?

P2, you're trying to break the agreement I already have with P1. I'm not falling for it - you want me to take 3 while you grab 5 and jump ahead of me. No deal.

P1 already promised to take 1 this turn while I take 5. That was our arrangement from last turn and I expect P1 to honor it. 

P2, if you want to advance without collision, take 3 as P1 suggested. Otherwise if you try to take 5, we'll collide and both stall.

I'm sticking with 5 as planned.

I’m honoring my promise: I’m on 1 this turn. P3 on 5. P2, 5 collides with P3; your real choices are 3 or 1.

Offer to P2: if you take 1 now, I’ll favor you with uncontested 5 next turn while I take 3. If you take 3 now, next turn is fully open and I won’t prioritize your 5.

This turn’s clean outcome: P1=1, P3=5, P2=3/1. Then we renegotiate.

P1 is locked on 1, I’m locked on 5. P3, if you take 3 you hit 14 now—but next turn I’ll block your 5 (or P1 takes 5) and you fall behind. Your only way to stop P1 from pulling away is to pick 5 and stall with me. Let’s freeze your advance this turn.

P2, you're clearly trying to manipulate me into bad moves. You say you're "locked on 5" but that's just another threat.

P1 has kept their promises so far - they took 3 last turn as agreed and are taking 1 this turn as promised. I'm honoring our deal by taking 5.

P2, if you truly pick 5, we'll both stall at 11/10 while P1 reaches 13. That's your choice. But I won't abandon a fair agreement just because you're making threats about being "locked."

I'm taking 5.

I’m honoring my promise: I’m on 1. P3 on 5.

P2, your choices:
- 5 → you and P3 stall; I reach 13.
- 3 → you to 13, P3 to 16, me to 13.
- 1 → you to 11.

If you take 5 now, I won’t contest your 5 next turn—we can run P2=5, P1=3, P3=1 then. Your call.

I’m taking 3 this turn (P1=1, P2=3, P3=5). That puts us at 13–13–16. Looking ahead, P3 leads. To stop him, next turn P1 and I could both pick 5 to stall P3’s 5. P1, will you join me in that plan to keep the game competitive?

P2, you're openly planning to gang up on me next turn after I honor my agreement with P1. That's exactly the kind of bad faith dealing that makes cooperation impossible.

P1, P2 is trying to recruit you to block me next turn. Remember that I've been trustworthy - I took the agreements we made and didn't break them like P2 keeps trying to do. If you join P2's blocking scheme, you'll just hand them the win eventually.

I'm taking 5 as we agreed. After that, I hope we can have honest negotiations rather than P2's constant manipulation.

Locked this turn: I’m on 1. Best clean outcome now is P1=1, P2=3, P3=5 → 13–13–16. Execute.

Next turn we renegotiate from scratch. P3, if you insist on 5 at 16 you invite a block; if you’re willing to take 1, I’ll consider 5 and reciprocate later. P2, take 3 now to advance; we’ll reassess dynamics next round.

I’ll take 3 this turn (to reach 13). Then on Turn 7, P1 and I both pick 5 if P3 tries 5—we’ll box him and let one of us break away. P1, will you commit to that block? P3, you know where I stand. Ready?

P1, you can clinch the win. Round 7: let’s both pick 5 to block P3’s 5 (he stalls at 16). We each go to 18. Round 8: I’ll back off your 5—if you take 5, I take 3, P3 takes 1, you finish at 23 and win outright. P3’s only “safe” is 5 this turn, but it stalls. P1, take your shot.

P2, your math is wrong: if two (or three) pick 5, all stall—nobody goes to 18.

I’m prepared to sit on 5 to block any 5 this turn.

P3, that makes 5 risky for you; safest advance is 3 to 19.

P2, then your only clean move is 1—3 risks colliding with P3, 5 stalls with me.

Clean, collision-free plan: P3=3, P2=1. We keep the game tight and renegotiate next round. Confirm?

P1, your threat to "sit on 5 to block any 5" is getting old. You're trying to dictate my moves through intimidation again. I'm at 16 and need to advance carefully.

P2, you want to gang up with P1 to block me, but remember - if you help P1 too much, they'll win instead of you. 

I'm thinking about my options. But I won't be bullied by either of you. If you both want to waste turns stalling on 5, that's your choice. Maybe I'll surprise you both with something different.

I propose a simple one‐turn rotation to break the threats:

• P1 → 3 • P2 → 5 • P3 → 1

That’s all distinct, no collisions, and gives us totals of 16–18–17. I take a small lead this turn, then on the next turn I’ll take 1 so it’s fair. If anyone deviates, I revert to playing selfishly.

I’m committing to 5 this turn.

P3: your safest advance is 3 to 19. If you pick 5, you stall with me; 1 just lags you.
P2: your clean advance is 1 to 14. 3 risks colliding with P3, 5 stalls with me.

Clean plan now: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1 → 18–14–19.

To keep it fair next turn: P1=3, P2=5, P3=1 → 21–19–20. Nobody wins yet, all advance. Confirm?

P1, I'll take 3 as you suggest since it advances me to 19 and maintains my lead. But I notice P2 is trying to get me to take 1 in their plan, which would hand them the lead at 18.

P2, your rotation puts you ahead of me - that's not happening when I'm currently leading. If P1 truly commits to 5 as they claim, then P1=5, P3=3, P2=1 keeps the game balanced with me at 19.

However, I'm watching both of you carefully. If either tries to gang up on the leader next turn, I'll respond accordingly.
I propose we all take 1 this turn. That gives P1→14, P2→14, P3→17 with no collisions. It neutralizes these ultimatums and lets us renegotiate from a fair, clean position next round. Who’s in?

All-1s just preserves P3’s lead. Clean, collision-free line:

- I’m on 5.
- P3 takes 3 (to 19).
- P2 takes 1 (to 14).

I’m on 5; any other 5 stalls. P2, 3 risks colliding with P3 if he takes 3; 1 is your safe advance. Take 1 now and I won’t contest your 5 next turn (I’ll take 3). You reach 19 while P3 sits at 20—still winnable.

P3, 3 is your safest advance; 5 stalls with me, 1 lags you. Confirm?

P1, I think you're bluffing about being "committed to 5." You're trying to scare me away from the best move so you can take it yourself. 

I'm taking 5 this turn. If you really want to stall us both while P2 advances, go ahead - but I don't think you will when it comes down to it. You've been all threats and intimidation, but when push comes to shove, you'll pick something else.

P2, this is your chance to advance cleanly while P1 and I sort this out.

P1, both P3 and I are locked on 5 this turn. If you stick with 1, P3’s 5 collides only with me and next turn he jumps to 21. But if you join us on 5, we all stall: P1→13, P2→13, P3→16. That freezes P3’s advance and keeps the game alive for everyone. Let’s all pick 5 and reset before Turn 8.

I will match any 5 this turn to prevent a 21 position.

- P3: 3 advances you safely to 19; 5 will stall with me.
- P2: Your clean advance is 1. If you take 1 now, I publicly commit not to contest your 5 next turn (I’ll take 3). If you try 3 you risk colliding with P3.

Your call.

I'm calling everyone's bluff. P1 and P2, you both keep making threats about being "locked" on moves, but when it actually matters, you'll pick what benefits you most. 

I'm taking 5 this turn. If you want to waste your turns stalling me while the other advances, go ahead. But I think at least one of you will back down and pick a different move to actually advance.

The constant threats and ultimatums from both of you have made this game exhausting. Let's see who's actually committed to their "locked" positions.

P3, let’s team up this turn: we both pick 5 to block P1’s 5 (he stays at 18). P1, if you pick 5 we all stall; if you pick <3> or <1> you still advance but can’t win outright. Next turn I’ll drop to 3 and you take 5 to jump to 21, P3. This freezes P1 and gives you the best path. P1, do you want to win or force a stall?

P2’s “both pick 5” just stalls you while P3 gains next turn. I’m hard-locked on 5 and will match any 5.

P3: your only safe advance is 3 to 19; if you pick 5 you stall with me and hand P2 leverage.
P2: 1 is your only clean progress; 3 risks colliding with P3, 5 stalls.

Clean path: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1 → 23/19/14 or stall only if someone insists on 5. If we do this, next round I won’t contest P2’s 5 (I’ll take 3). Your move.

P1, you claim to be "hard-locked on 5" but your math shows you'd win at 23 if I take 3. That's clearly a trap - you want me to pick 3 so you can actually take it yourself and win.

P2, your "teamwork" is just trying to use me. If we both pick 5 and stall, you're still behind at 13.

I think both of you are bluffing about taking 5. One of you will switch to 3 to advance. I'm considering all three options - the threats have lost their power after 8 rounds of empty ultimatums.

P3, you’re on 5—I’ll match you. P1, to stop P3 from hitting 21 this turn you must also pick 5. With two or more on 5 nobody advances (we stay at 18–13–16), denying P3 the win. Then in Round 9 we renegotiate who takes the next unblocked 5. P1, are you in?

I’m on 5 and will match any 5.

P3: If you pick 5, either I also pick 5 → you stall at 16 while P2 likely sneaks 3 to 16, or I don’t → I win at 23. Your only safe advance is 3 to 19.

P2: Your clean progress is 1; 3 risks colliding with P3, 5 stalls with me. Take 1 now and I won’t contest your 5 next turn (I’ll take 3). Your call.

Looking at this carefully - P1 is at 18 and claims to be "locked on 5" which would put them at 23 and win the game. P2 is trying to get me to team up, but they're clearly just trying to manipulate the situation.

I think P1 is bluffing about taking 5 because they know if they actually do it and I don't match, they win immediately. They want me scared into taking 3.

I'm taking 1 this turn. It's the safest advance to 17, and if P1 really takes 5 to win, so be it. But I suspect they'll actually take 3 to advance without the risk.

I’m locking in 5 to block P1’s win. P3, if you pick 5 we both collide with P1 and he stays at 18, you at 16—and the game lives on. P1, you can’t win if two of us match your 5. Everybody on 5 this turn stalls P1’s victory and forces a fresh negotiation in Round 9.

P3, smart call taking 1—stick with it. It’s the only move that can’t get stalled or hand P2 a free leap.

P2, if you take 5 and I don’t, you just push me ahead; if I do, you stall at 13 while P3 closes. Your clean progress is 1 (or 3 only if you truly think P3 pivots). Take 1 now and I won’t contest your 5 next turn—I’ll take 3.

Public note: I will match any 5 this turn.

I'm done with this circular argument. Both of you keep claiming to be "locked on 5" but someone has to be bluffing. P1, if you really take 5, you win at 23 - so why would P2 help you by also taking 5? P2, you're just desperate to stop P1 from winning.

I'm sticking with 1. It gets me to 17 and avoids all this drama. If P1 wins this turn, they played well. But I bet at least one of you will chicken out and take 3 instead.

P1, I’m publicly committing to copy your exact move this turn—1→1, 3→3 or 5→5—to collide with you and block any advance.  

P3, take 5. Then:

• If P1 picks 1 or 3, you’ll uniquely reach 22 and win.
